titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Witness to Guantanamo Video Collection, 2009-2017 RL.11691

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-03-23 10:08:27 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

physdesc.extent: High (ProRes) and low (MP4) resolution Apple MOV files.

did.abstract: One hundred fifty-three video files of interviews with 149 former detainees and others -- attornies, chaplains, guards, government officials, human rights advocates, journalists -- who witnessed the impact of the Guantanamo Bay detention center in the post-911 years. An additional 346 files, short clips extracted from the interviews featured on the Witness to Guantanamo site, are also included.
did.langmaterial: Materials in English, French, German, Arabic, and Uyghur.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, became the site of the detention center for suspected al Qaeda and Taliban operatives. Peter Jan Honigsberg, a professor at the University of San Francisco School of Law, began Witness to Guantanamo (WtG) in fall 2008, after realizing that no one was filming, collecting and preserving the voices and stories of Guantanamo. He modelled Witness to Guantanamo after grassroots truth commissions and the Shoah Foundation's collection of Holocaust survivor testimonies.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. See individual interviews for known use restrictions. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Witness to Guantanamo Video Collection was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Witness to Guantanamo Video Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Craig Breaden, May 2019 and March 2021.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0164 and 2020-0082.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: One hundred fifty-three video files of interviews with 149 former detainees and others -- attornies, chaplains, guards, government officials, human rights advocates, journalists -- who witnessed the impact of the Guantanamo Bay detention center in the post-911 years. A wide range of topics includes physical and psychological torture, religious faith, medical care, interrogation, trials, and women at Guantanamo. An additional 346 files, short clips extracted from the interviews featured on the Witness to Guantanamo site, are also included.

did.langmaterial: See specific interview for interview language.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: See specific interview for access restrictions.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: See specific interview for use restrictions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviews with 149 former detainees and others -- attornies, chaplains, guards, government officials, human rights advocates, journalists -- who witnessed the impact of the Guantanamo Bay detention center in the post-911 years. A wide range of topics includes physical and psychological torture, religious faith, medical care, interrogation, trials, and women at Guantanamo. Short clips extracted from the interviews, used on the Witness to Guantanamo website, are listed where available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rushan Abbas, female, age 42, was an interpreter for the Uyghur detainees in Guantanamo from 2002-2003. When the men were released, she stayed with them in Bermuda for two weeks to help them readjust.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Feroz Ali Abbasi, male, age 30, British, was detained in Guantanamo from January 10, 2002 until January 25, 2005, when he was returned to Britain.

did.unittitle: Abbasi, Feroz Ali - Interview master file

Abbasi, Feroz Ali - short clip - EnduringGuantanamo
Abbasi, Feroz Ali - short clip - testname
Abd al Mahsen al Zamel, Adel Zamel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Adel Zamel Abd al Mahsen al Zamel, male, age 47, Kuwaiti, was detained in Guantanamo from May 1, 2002 until November 2, 2005, when he was returned to Kuwait and later acquitted in a Kuwaiti court.

did.unittitle: Abd al Mahsen al Zamel, Adel Zamel - Interview master file

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Salahidin Abdulahat, male, age 32, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from 2002 until June 11, 2009, when he was transferred to Bermuda.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen Abraham, male, age unknown, served with the Office for the Administrative Review of Enemy Combatants from September 2004 through March 2005, and was the first officer to publicly criticize the operations of the Combatant Status Review Tribunals. His affidavit was key to the United States Supreme Court decision in Al Odah v. United States, and subsequently Boumediene v. Bush.

did.unittitle: Abraham, Stephen - short clip - Blood on Our Hands
Abraham, Stephen - short clip - CSRTs Were Advisory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Adams, male, age 58, was an Army Brigadier General, and on September 11, 2001, was serving as Deputy Director for European Policy in the Office of the Secretary of Defense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ahmed Adil, male, age 33, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from early 2002 to May 5, 2006, when he was released to Albania. In May 2005, his Combatant Status Review Tribunal determined he was not an enemy combatant, but he was not relased until the following year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ruhal Ahmed, male, age 28, British, was detained in Guantanamo from February 11, 2002 until March 9, 2004, when he was returned to Britain, and released without charge.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only with donor approval, via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mohamed Aouzar, male, age 32, Moroccan, was detained in Guantanamo from February 4, 2002 until July 31, 2004 when he was returned to Morocco, where he was eventually acquitted in 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Christopher Arendt, male, age 27, was stationed as a guard in Guantanamo for 10 months beginning in January 2004. After finishing his tour in 2008, he gave public testimony about the mistreatment of detainees in Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Zakirjan Asam, male, age 35, Russian and Uzbekistani, was detained in Guantanamo from June 14, 2002 until November 17, 2006, when he was released to Albania. During his Combatant Status Review Tribunal, he was determined to not be an enemy combatant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Saad Madi Saad al Azmi, male, age 31, Kuwaiti, was detained in Guantanamo from May 1, 2002 until November 2, 2005 when he was returned to Kuwait, tried and acquitted.

did.unittitle: Azmi, Saad Madi Saad al - Interview master file

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sean Baker, male, age 45, was a prison guard at Guantanamo beginning in November 2002. On January 24, 2003, during a role-playing exercise to train soldiers in a forced cell extraction (erf), he played the role of a detainee. He was severely beaten by fellow soldiers who believed he was an actual detainee, and sustained a brain injury, vision loss, and ongoing seizures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jamil El-Banna, male, age 49, a Jordanian citizen of Palestinian descent, was detained in Guantanamo from March 2003 until December 19, 2007, when he was released to Britain.

did.unittitle: Banna, Jamil El- - Interview master file
Banna, Jamil El- - short clip - WhenIRememberICan'tSpeak

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Akhtar Qasem Basil, male, age 34, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 10, 2002 until May 5, 2006, when he was released to Albania. In 2004-2005, his Combatant Status Review Tribunal determined he was not an enemy combatant, but he was not released until the following year.

did.unittitle: Basil, Akhtar Qasem - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moazzam Begg, male, age 41, British, was detained in Guantanamo from February 6, 2003 until January 25, 2005, when he was returned without charge to Britain.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Bellinger, male, age unknown, held several senior Presidential appointments, including Legal Adviser to the Department of State (2005-2009) under Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, and Senior Associate Counsel to the President and Legal Adviser to the National Security Council at the White House (2001-2005).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brahim Benchakroun, male, age 32, Moroccan, was held in Guantanamo for nearly three years before he was released to Morocco in August 2004 at age 24. In April 2014, he was killed while fighting in Syria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mourad Benchellali, male, age 28, French, was detained in Guantanamo from January 17, 2002 until July 26, 2004, when he was returned to France. He is currently public speaking in France, in the hope that by hearing his story, young people will not join ISIS or participate in suicide attacks.

did.unittitle: Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - Interview master file
Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - short clip - HowtoFightRadicalIslam
Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - short clip - Interrogations

Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - short clip - PsychologicalWarfare
Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - short clip - reliefatAmericans
Benchellali, Mourad, interview 1 - short clip - TurningMyGuantrienceintoSomethingPositive

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mourad Benchellali, male, age 28, French, was detained in Guantanamo from January 17, 2002 until July 26, 2004, when he was returned to France. He is currently public speaking in France, in the hope that by hearing his story, young people will not join ISIS or participate in suicide attacks.

did.unittitle: Benchellali, Mourad, interview 2 - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradford Berenson, male, age 50, was Associate Counsel to President George W. Bush (2001-2003), and worked on the authorization for military commissions, detainee and anti-terrorism litigation, and the creation of the Department of Homeland Security.

did.unittitle: Berenson, Bradford - short clip - If We Could Take Back the Iraq War We Would
did.container: BradfordBerenson_If We Could Take Back the Iraq War We Would.mp4

did.unittitle: Berenson, Bradford - short clip - Legal Precedents vs. the Temper of the Times
did.container: BradfordBerenson_Legal Precedents vs. the Temper of the Times.mp4

did.unittitle: Berenson, Bradford - short clip - Obama Agrees with a Bush Policy
did.container: BradfordBerenson_Obama Agrees with a Bush Policy.mp4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas Berg, male, age 60, helped the Defense Department set up war crimes tribunals for captured al-Qaeda and Taliban prisoners after 9/11. The tribunals were based on the Uniform Code of Military Justice and the Geneva Conventions, but the Pentagon civilian leadership rejected them. He also served as Judge Advocate General, military legal adviser, to Gen. Rick Baccus in Guantanamo.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Haj Boudella, male, age 49, an Algerian-born Bosnian citizen, was detained in Guantanamo from January 20, 2002 until December 16, 2008 when he returned to his family in Bosnia after the landmark Supreme Court decision Boumediene v. Bush.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lakhdar Boumediene, male, age 43, Algerian, was detained in Guantanamo from January 20, 2002 until May 15, 2009, when he was released to France. A federal judge ruled that he was not being lawfully held and ordered his release on Nov. 20, 2008, but he was not released for another six months.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Bourdon, male, age 60, was the lawyer for French detainees Nizar Sassi and Mourad Benchellali, and assisted in their release back to France in 2004, represented them later when they were accused of criminal association with a terrorist organization, and filed a case in French court against the U.S. for their torture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marion (Spike) Bowman, male, age 66, is the former Senior Counsel to the FBI, and the former Deputy National Counter Intelligence Executive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yvonne Bradley, female, age unknown, was a United States Air Force Attorney who vigorously represented former detainee, Binyam Mohamed, a former British resident who went on hunger strike to protest against the conditions at Guantanamo. All charges were dropped by the U.S. Government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Brant, male, age 58, was the Director of the Naval Criminal Investigative Service from 1997 through 2005. He reported questionable interrogation techniques to Alberto Mora, then General Counsel of the Navy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jennifer Bryson, female, age 44, was an interrogator at Guantanamo Bay from 2004-2006, and the first female team chief. She has since written articles arguing that the U.S. should reject torture and use rapport-based interrogation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bob Buehn, male, age 60, was commander of the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base from 2000 to 2003, and helped establish the Joint Task Force Guantanamo.

did.unittitle: Buehn, Bob - short clip - Did Not Know What Was Coming
did.container: Bob Buehn-Did Not Know What Was Coming.mp4

did.unittitle: Buehn, Bob - short clip - Right Intentions, Wrong Effects
Buehn, Bob - short clip - The Mayor of Guantanamo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Redouane Chekkouri, male, age 40, Moroccan, was detained in Guantanamo from April 30, 2002 until July 31, 2004, when he was returned to Morrocco. Upon returning to Morocco, Chekkouri (along with four other ex-Guantanamo detainees) was put on trial for charges related to terrorism, but was eventually acquitted in 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Erwin Chemerinsky, male, age 56, is the founding Dean of the University of California, Irvine School of Law, and a top expert in constitutional law. He is the author of seven books and over 200 law review articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jim Clemente, male, age 50 was an FBI Supervisory Special Agent and was stationed in Guantanamo to consult on interrogation methods and the development of an interrogation plan. He took a public stand against the tactics being used, saying they violated the U.S. Torture Statute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Geoffrey Corn, male, age 50, served in the United States military for 22 years, and was an expert witness for the Military Commissions in Guantanamo Bay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Damien Corsetti, male, age 33, was an Army interrogator in Bagram, Afghanistan and Abu Ghraib, Iraq where he allegedly assaulted and mistreated prisoners, and was known as the "King of Torture." He was cleared by a military jury of all charges on June 1, 2006, and was honorably discharged from the United States Army.

did.unittitle: Corsetti, Damien, interview 1 - Interview master file
Corsetti, Damien, interview 1 - short clip - BendingLikeAPalmTreeInTheWind

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Damien Corsetti, male, age 33, was an Army interrogator in Bagram, Afghanistan and Abu Ghraib, Iraq where he allegedly assaulted and mistreated prisoners, and was known as the "King of Torture." He was cleared by a military jury of all charges on June 1, 2006, and was honorably discharged from the United States Army.

did.unittitle: Corsetti, Damien, interview 2 - Interview master file
Corsetti, Damien, interview 2 - short clip - DrunkonPowerat22

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Damien Corsetti, male, age 35, was an Army interrogator in Bagram, Afghanistan and Abu Ghraib, Iraq where he allegedly assaulted and mistreated prisoners, and was known as the "King of Torture." He was cleared by a military jury of all charges on June 1, 2006, and was honorably discharged from the United States Army.

did.unittitle: Corsetti, Damien, interview 3 - Interview master file
Corsetti, Damien, interview 3 - short clip - IllBeYourBadGuy

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: He wants to approve transcript before release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Greg Craig, male, age 66, was White House Counsel from 2009 to 2010, and drafted the executive orders banning the use of torture by government personnel, and calling for the closure of the Guantanamo Bay Detention Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cori Crider, female, age 33, is an attorney and former Legal Director of Reprieve, and has represented many Guantanamo Bay detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sondra Crosby, female, age 56, is co-founder and co-director of the Boston University Forensic Medical Evaluation Group, which provides medical forensic documentation of torture and other physical abuse. She was one of the first civilian doctors permitted to independently examine detainees while still in Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jamil Dakwar, male, age 42, is Director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Human Rights Program, which includes work on counter-terrorism and Guantanamo. He is also the ACLU's Main Representative to the United Nations, and has testified on the U.S.'s human rights violations in that capacity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Morris Davis, male, age 51, was appointed as the third Chief Prosecutor in the Guantanamo military commissions in September 2005. He resigned from the position in October 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mark Denbeaux, male, age 67, is a law professor and the director of the Center for Policy and Research at Seton Hall University School of Law. The Center has directed numerous studies on the Guantanamo Bay detention camp and its operations, based on data by the United States Department of Defense, and testified on the findings to Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tarek Dergoul, male, age 32, a British citizen of Moroccan descent, was detained in Guantanamo from May 2, 2002 until March 9, 2004, when he was returned to Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Matt Diaz, male, age 46, was deputy director of the Guantanamo detention center's legal office from July 2004 until January 2005. Because of concerns about the legal and physical treatment of the detainees, he sent an anonymous card to the Center for Constitutional Rights revealing the 550 previously unreleased names of the detainees. He was later convicted of criminal charges and given a six-month sentence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: J. Wells Dixon, male, age 42, is Senior Staff Attorney at the Center for Constitutional Rights, where he specializes in challenging unlawful Guantanamo detentions in federal court, before the military commissions at Guantanamo, and in international proceedings.

did.unittitle: Dixon, J. Wells - Interview master file
Dixon, J. Wells - short clip - FailuretoClose
Dixon, J. Wells - short clip - GuantanamoandtheAmericanLandscape

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dennis Edney, male, age 65, has been representing Canadian citizen Omar Khadr--who was captured and brought to Guantanamo as a juvenile--for over a decade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mark Fallon, male, age 56, served for more than 30 years in the federal law enforcement and counterintelligence community, including as Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) Special Agent, and Assistant Director for Training at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center within the Department of Homeland Security.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Frakt, male, age 40, was an attorney with the US Air Force Reserve JAG Corps and represented Guantanamo detainees facing trial by military tribunal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Gelles, male, age 51, is the former Chief Psychologist for the Navy Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) at Guantanamo. He notably uncovered the unauthorized use of abusive interrogation techniques of detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Candace Gorman, female, age 56, shut down her civil rights practice to focus solely on getting her two clients out of Guantanamo, closing Guantanamo and bringing those responsible for these war crimes to justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donald Guter, male, age 63, was a JAG Admiral and served as special counsel to the Chief of Naval Operations. He became the 37th Judge Advocate General of the Navy from 2000-2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gitanjali Gutierrez, female, age 41, is an attorney with the Center for Constitutional Rights, and was the first habeas lawyer to visit her clients in Guantanamo in September 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Maha Habib, female, age 47, is the wife of Mamdouh Habib, an Australian citizen detained in Guantanamo from May 5, 2002 until January 27, 2005, and was then returned to Australia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mamdouh Habib, male, age 56, Egyptian-born Australian citizen, was detained in Guantanamo from May 5, 2002 until January 27, 2005, when he was returned to Australia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jonathan Hafetz, male, age unknown, works for the National Security Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, has helped coordinate the Guantanamo detainee habeas corpus litigation since its earliest stages, including testifying before Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sami Al Hajj, male, age 43, Sudanese, was detained in Guantanamo from June 14, 2002 until April 30, 2008, when he was released without charge to Sudan. While in Guantanamo, he went on a hunger strike to protest the conditions, and refused to end his strike until he was released.

did.unittitle: Hajj, Sami Al - Interview master file
Hajj, Sami Al - short clip - BeingReleased
Hajj, Sami Al - short clip - TheGoodThatCameOutofIt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Adil Hakimjan, male, age 39, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 2002 until May 5, 2006. In April 2009, he was granted asylum in Sweden.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kauvser Hakimjan, female, age 40, is the sister of former Guantanamo detainee Adil Hakimjan. They were reunited in Albania in 2006, and both granted asylum in Sweden in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Julia Hall, female, age 51, is Amnesty International's expert on counter terrorism and human rights. Previously, as senior legal counsel in Terrorism and Counter-Terrorism at Human Rights Watch, she monitored the Guantanamo military commissions trial of Salim Hamdan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rafiq Al Hami, male, age 43, Tunisian, was detained in Guantanamo seven years, five of which were spent in solitary confinement, from February 2003 until January 24, 2010, when he was transferred to Slovakia. In 2013, he left his Tunisian family and small business to join an armed group in Syria, and two years later his family were told he had been killed.

did.unittitle: Hami, Rafiq Al - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Janet Hamlin, female, age 56, has been the only courtroom sketch artist for the Guantanamo Bay military commission hearings from 2006 to the present time. Because cameras are not permitted during hearings, Hamlin's work provides the only visual representation available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nicolas Henin, male, age 39, a French journalist, was held captive by ISIS militants from June 2013 until April 2014. As a freelance journalist, he covered the conflict in Iraq from 2002 to 2004, and subsequent crises and conflicts in Sudan, Somalia and Yemen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bev Hicks, female, age 69, the stepmother of former Guantanamo Bay detainee David Hicks, worked tirelessly for years with David's attorneys, and on February 19, 2015, got his conviction vacated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terry Hicks, male, age 66, is the father of Australian former Guantanamo Bay detainee David Hicks. He worked tirelessly for years with David's attorneys, and on February 19, 2015, got his conviction vacated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terry Holdbrooks, male, age 26, served as a prison guard at Guantanamo from June 2003 until July 2004, converting to Islam during this time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nageeb Al Hosani, male, age 33, Moroccan, was detained in Guantanamo from February 7, 2002 until February 7, 2006, when he was returned to Morocco.

did.unittitle: Hosani, Nageeb Al - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kristine Husky, female, age 42, has represented over fifteen Guantanamo detainees since 2002, including Omar Khadr, the young Canadian citizen charged with war crimes, in Rasul v. Bush in 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vincent Iacopino, male, age 60, is the senior medical advisor to Physicians for Human Rights, and the principle organizer behind the U.N. Istanbul Protocol, which provides guidelines on effective torture investigation and documentation. He has also testified in a number of Guantanamo detainee hearings.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only with donor approval, via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mustafa Ait Idir, male, age 39, a citizen of Algeria and Bosnia and Herzegovina, was detained in Guantanamo from January 20, 2002 until December 16, 2008 when he was released to Bosnia and Herzegovina after a federal judge ruled that he was not being lawfully held.

did.unittitle: Idir, Mustafa Ait - Interview master file
Idir, Mustafa Ait - short clip - erf

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jalil Jalaldin, male, age 30, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 12, 2002 until June 11, 2009, when he was released to Bermuda. He won his habeas corpus suit in 2008, but was not released until the following year.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only via typescript in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abdul Rahim Janko, male, age 35, Syrian-Kurd, was detained in Guantanamo from May 1, 2002 until Oct. 9, 2009, when he was released to Belgium.

did.unittitle: Janko, Abdul Rahim - Interview master file
Janko, Abdul Rahim - short clip - NotaBadPerson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shayana Kadidal, male, age 48, is a Senior Managing Attorney at the Center for Constitutional Rights, and has worked on the Guantanamo Global Justice Initiative, coordinating legal representation for Guantanamo detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abdullah Kamel Abdullah Kamel, male, age 37, Kuwaiti, was detained in Guantanamo from February 11, 2002 until September 14, 2006, when he was repatriated to Kuwait.

did.unittitle: Kamel, Abdullah Kamel Abudallah - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Imad Kanouni, male, age 32, French, was detained in Guantanamo from 2002 until July 26, 2004, when he was returned to France. In April 2006, he was acquitted by a French court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen Kenny, male, age 57, represented David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib, two Australians detained in Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abdurahman Khadr, male, age 30, a Canadian national of Egyptian origin, was detained in Guantanamo from March 23, 2003 until November 18, 2003, when he was released to Bosnia and Herzegovina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Murat Kurnaz, male 27, age, Turkish citizen and legal resident of Germany, was detained in Guantanamo from February 13, 2002 until August 24, 2006, when he was released to Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mohammed Souleimani Laalami, male, age 36, was detained in Guantanamo from February 2, 2002 until February 7, 2006, when he was released to Morocco. Upon his return to Morocco, Laalami was convicted of "forming a criminal group" and sentenced to five years, however he won his appeal in May 2007 and was acquitted. In 2013, he was killed while fighting in Syria.

did.unittitle: Laalami, Mohammed Souleimani - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Saber Lahmar, male, age 41, Algerian, was detained in Guantanamo from January 20, 2002 until November 30, 2009, when he won his Habeas Corpus petition and was released to France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Daniel Lakemacher, male, age 27, was a Hospital Corpsman deployed to Guantanamo for six months in 2008. He was granted discharge on September 11, 2009 as a conscientious objector.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Lehnert, male, age 60, was the first commander of the Guantanamo Bay detention facility from December 21, 2001 until March 28, 2002. In May 2015, General Lehnert authored a letter in support of closing Guantanamo Bay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paul Lewis, male, age 58, was the Department of Defense Special Envoy for Guantanamo Closure from October 2013 until February 2, 2017, and during his tenure was able to reduce the number of detainees remaining at the prison to 41.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Lietzau, male, age 53, was Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Detainee Policy, and Deputy Legal Adviser to the National Security Council, and led the United States negotiating team responsible for defining war crimes for the International Criminal Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Lindh, male, age 58, is the father of John Walker Lindh, a 20 year-old American citizen captured in Afghanistan in November 2001 and held for 54 days without access to family or lawyers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alan Liotta, male, age 58, was appointed Principal Director of the Office of Detainee Policy in the Department of Defense in 2006 and was responsible for negotiating the transfers of more than 380 Guantanamo detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bahtiyar Mahnut, male, age 34, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 2002 until March 22, 2010, when he was released to Switzerland. In October 2008, he won his habeas corpus suit, however he was not released until both himself and his brother were granted political asylum in 2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brittain Mallow, male, age 58, was Commander of the Criminal Investigation Task Force (CITF) (2002-2005), and ordered the task force to discontinue the increasingly coercive interrogation tactics being used at the Guantanamo Bay detention center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Khalil Mamut, male, age 32 or 33, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from October 6, 2002 until June 11, 2009, when he was released to Bermuda.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Prior to viewing the interview, permission must be obtained from either David Remes, Al-marfadi's lawyer (remesdh@gmail.com), or Ashraf Michael, his interpreter (ashrafmichael@gmail.com). Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hussein Al-marfadi, male, age 37, Yemeni, was detained in Guantanamo from May 9, 2003 until November 20, 2014, when he was released to Slovakia.

did.unittitle: Marfadi, Hussein Al-, interview 1 - Interview master file

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Prior to viewing the interview, permission must be obtained from either David Remes, Al-marfadi's lawyer (remesdh@gmail.com), or Ashraf Michael, his interpreter (ashrafmichael@gmail.com). Interview may be accessed only via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hussein Al-marfadi, male, age 37, Yemeni, was detained in Guantanamo from May 9, 2003 until November 20, 2014, when he was released to Slovakia.

did.unittitle: Marfadi, Hussein Al-, interview 2 - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joseph Margulies, male, age 51, was Counsel of Record in Rasul v. Bush (2004), the case that established statutory habeas rights for Guantanamo detainees, and is counsel for Abu Zubaydah, a "high-value" detainee whose interrogation led to the infamous "torture memos." He also testified at the first Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on detainee issues in 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Mcfadden, male, age 56, worked at the Naval Criminal Investigative Service from 2008-2011, serving as Deputy Assistant Director of Counterintelligence Operations for his final year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ronald Meister, male, age 69, has successfully represented since 2014 a Navy nurse at Guantanamo Bay who refused to carry out orders to force-feed detainee hunger-strikers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Juan Mendez, male, age 71, was UN Special Rapporteur on Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman and Degrading Treatment or Punishment from November 2010 until October 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Brent Mickum, male, age 58, is an attorney who represented Guantanamo detainees Bisher Al Rawi, Jamil El Banna, and Martin Mubanga, as well as Abu Zubaydah, one of the "high-value" detainees.

did.unittitle: Mickum, George Brent - Interview master file
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - APoliticalBeing
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - SystematicallyTrimmingtheConstitution
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - ThereIsNoLaw
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - ThereIsNoLaw
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - ThereIsNoLaw2
Mickum, George Brent - short clip - ThereIsNoLaw3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ben Moujane Mohamed, male, age 31, Moroccan, was detained in Guantanamo from January 14, 2002 until October, 11 2006, when he was returned to Morocco.

did.unittitle: Mohamed, Ben Moujane - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alberto Mora, male, age 58, was the General Counsel of the Navy in 2001 and led efforts in the Department of Defense to oppose Bush administration legal theories that allowed harsh interrogation tactics at the U.S. detention camp in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ayub Muhammed, male, age 25, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from May 2002 until May 5, 2006, when he was released to Albania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Khaled Ben Mustafa, male, age 38, French, was detained at Guantanamo February 13, 2002 until March 7, 2005, when he was returned to France for trial. Originally convicted in France in 2007, his trial was overturned on appeal and he was released in February 2009. Despite having already served the one-year sentence they faced, the Court of Cassation ordered a re-trial on February 17, 2010.

did.unittitle: Mustafa, Khaled Ben - Interview master file
Mustafa, Khaled Ben - short clip - ADayintheLife
Mustafa, Khaled Ben - short clip - AllPartoftheSystem
Mustafa, Khaled Ben - short clip - AllPartoftheSystem-old
Mustafa, Khaled Ben - short clip - DetaineesProtestingandMilitaryResponse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Emile Nakhleh, male, age 74, was a senior intelligence service officer and director of the Political Islam Strategic Analysis Program in the Directorate of Intelligence at the CIA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brandon Neely, male, age 30, was stationed as a guard in Guantanamo from January 2002 until March 2004. In January 2010, he flew to the United Kingdom to meet with former detainees with whom he had reconnected via Facebook.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Torin Nelson, male, age 45, was an interrogator in Guantanamo Bay and Afghanistan, and has spoken out against the interrogation practices at Abu Ghraib.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Newton, male, age 53, served in the U.S. State Department's Office of War Crimes Issues from 1999-2002. As the senior advisor to the Ambassador-at-Large, Newton implemented a wide range of policy positions related to the law of armed conflict.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Adel Noori., male, age 40, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from May 6, 2002 until October 31, 2009, when he was released to Palau. He won his habeas corpus suit in 2008, but was not released until the following year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manfred Nowak, male, age 66, is one of the leading human rights activists in the world. He was the United Nations Special Rapporteur on Torture from 2004-2010, and one of the five authors of a UN report on the detention of captives in Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Khalid Al-Odah, male, age 58, is the father of detainee Fawzi Al-Odah, and the founder of the Kuwaiti Family Committee, an organization formed in 2004 by the relatives of detainees to advocate for their just treatment under the U.S. Judicial system. He campaigned for the release of 12 Kuwaiti detainees, the last of which, his son, was released from Guantanamo November 5, 2014, after almost 13 years of detainment without charge.

did.unittitle: Odah, Khalid Al- - Interview master file
Odah, Khalid Al- - short clip - GiveThemtheRight
Odah, Khalid Al- - short clip - MissingOurSon
Odah, Khalid Al- - short clip - OnBehalfofFawzi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barbara Olshansky, female, age 56, created and directed the advocacy project on behalf of Guantanamo detainees at the Center for Constitutional Rights, and is the author of "Secret Trials and Executions: Military Tribunals and the Threat to Democracy," and "Democracy Detained: Secret Unconstitutional Practices in the U.S. War on Terror."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vijay Padmanabhan, male, age 34, worked in the U.S. State Department (2003-2008) as lead counsel on law of war litigation, collaborated with the Justice Department on Supreme Court cases, and led an inter-agency policy coordination committee on U.S. detention policy in the conflict with al Qaida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gareth Peirce, female, age 73, is a human rights attorney representing those accused of terrorist activity, including British citizens Moazzam Begg and Shakar Aamer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alka Pradhan, female, age 35, is the Human Rights Counsel for the Guantanamo Bay Military Commission of the Department of Defense, and was also Counsel for The Constitution Project's Task-Force on Detainee Treatment, co-authoring a comprehensive report on U.S. detention practices since 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pierre-Richard Prosper, male, age 51, was the second United States Ambassador-at-Large for War Crimes Issues, the lead diplomat engaging with nations whose citizens were held in Guantanamo. He held the position under President George W. Bush from 2001 to 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abubakir Qasem, male, age 40, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 8, 2002 until May 5, 2006, when he was released to Albania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abdul Ghappar Abdul Rahman, male, age 36, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from June 10, 2002 until October 31, 2009, when he was released to Palau.

did.unittitle: Rahman, Abdul Ghappar Abdul - Interview master file
Rahman, Abdul Ghappar Abdul - short clip - english
Rahman, Abdul Ghappar Abdul - short clip - goldenyears
Rahman, Abdul Ghappar Abdul - short clip - learningenglish

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shafiq Rasul, male, age 32, British, was detained in Guantanamo from February 5, 2002 until March 9, 2004, when he was returned to Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Ratner, male, age 66, is an attorney and the President of the Center for Constitutional Rights, and has represented Guantanamo detainees in front of the United States Supreme Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bisher al Rawi, male, age 43, an Iraqi citizen and resident of the UK, was detained in Guantanamo for four years (Feburary 2003- March 2007), and then released to Britain without charge.

did.unittitle: Rawi, Bisher al - Interview master file
Rawi, Bisher al - short clip - GettingBacktoNormal
Rawi, Bisher al - short clip - ThePainICarryInside
Rawi, Bisher al - short clip - UnnecessaryPunishment

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: He crossed out mediation/arbitration clause in contract.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marc Van den Reeck, male, age unknown, is a Belgium Ambassador, and headed the Belgium delegation to Guantanamo to interview (and eventually resettle in Belgium) Syrian/Kurdish detainee Abdul Rahim Janko.

did.unittitle: Reeck, Marc Van den - Interview master file
Reeck, Marc Van den - short clip - NowYou'reDealingWithTheBelgians
Reeck, Marc Van den - short clip - PreparingForJanko

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Remes, male, age 57, gave up his career in corporate law to focus exclusively on representing Guantanamo Bay detainees. He represented Adnan Latif, a young Yemeni who died in September 2012 at Guantanamo Bay under suspicious circumstances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carol Rosenberg, female, age 52, a journalist for The Miami Herald, has covered the Guantanamo Bay detention center longer than any journalist, beginning with the arrival of the first prisoners on January 11, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Polly Rossdale, female, age 38, was Deputy Director of Reprieve for two years, and for four years before that coordinated the Life after Guantanamo project, the only program dedicated to the rehabilitation of prisoners freed from Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mahfoud Yahdih Ould Salahi, male, age unknown, Mauritanian, discovered his brother, Mohamedou Ould Slahi, was being held in Guantanamo from a copy of Der Spiegel, a German weekly news magazine. He then worked tirelessly to raise awareness and get his brother released, which happened on Ocotber 17, 2016, after 14 years of detainment without charge.

did.unittitle: Salahi, Mahfoud Yahdih Ould - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nizar Sassi, male, age 38, French of Tunisian descent, was detained in Guantanamo from February 15, 2002 until July 26, 2004, when he was returned to France. In 2012, Sassi and two other former French detainees filed a criminal complaint in Paris against the U.S. for use of torture in Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charlie Savage, male, age 41, reports for The New York Times on national security and legal policy issues, including presidential power, surveillance, drone strikes, torture, secrecy, leak investigations, and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tariq al-Sawah, male, age 58, a citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Egypt, was detained in Guantanamo from May 6, 2002 until January 20, 2016, when he was returned to Bosnia and Herzegovina. While in Guantanamo, he agreed to cooperate with the U.S. military, and became one of the most significant informants held at the prison. As a reward for his assistance, he was housed in a little fenced-in compound at the prison and provided a relatively easy life.

did.unittitle: Sawah, Tariq al- - Interview master file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hina Shamsi, female, age 45, is Director of the ACLU National Security Project where she focuses on the intersection of national security and counterterrorism policies with international human rights and humanitarian law.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: MichelleShephard, female, age 40, is an investigative reporter for the Toronto Star who has traveled to Guantanamo more than two dozen times to tell the stories of detainees, including Omar Khadr, one of the youngest Guantanamo prisoners and a Canadian citizen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albert Shimkus, male, age 66, was the commanding officer and joint task force surgeon at the U.S. Naval Hospital in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba from January 2002 to July 2003.

did.unittitle: Shimkus, Albert - short clip - BSCT-Behavioral Science Control Team
Shimkus, Albert - short clip - Looking Back

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marshal Skaggs, male, age 35, joined the military at age 20, and although trained in counterintelligence, he was assigned to be an interrogator after 9/11.

did.unittitle: Skaggs, Marshal - short clip - How to Keep This From Happening Again
did.container: MarshallSkaggs_How to Keep This From Happening Again.mp4

did.unittitle: Skaggs, Marshal - short clip - The More You Understand a Person, the More of a Person They Are to You
did.container: MarshallSkaggs_The More You Understand a Person, the More of a Person They Are to You.mp4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cliff Sloan, male, age 57, was the Special Envoy for Guantanamo Closure for the Obama administration from July 2013 to December 2104, transferring 44 men out of Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clive Stafford Smith, male, age 51, is the founder of Reprieve and has spent 25 years working on civil rights issues, including achieving due process for prisoners detained in Guantanamo.

did.unittitle: Smith, Clive Stafford - Interview master file
Smith, Clive Stafford - short clip - CensoredbyAmericans
Smith, Clive Stafford - short clip - HowtoKeepAmericaSafe
Smith, Clive Stafford - short clip - SecretListofPrisoners

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ali Soufan, male, age 43, one of a few FBI agents who spoke Arabic in 2001, publicly criticized the CIA for not sharing information with him that might have led to uncovering and preventing the 9/11 attacks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Souza, male, age 41, was a biomedical equipment repair technician in the Guantanamo Bay detention center medical clinic from July to December of 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuel Supervielle, male, age 55, was the chief military lawyer at Southern Command, and the senior military lawyer for detention operations at Guantanamo Bay. In the spirit of transparency, as the first planeload of detainees was about to arrive in Guantanamo, he invited the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to visit the base.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kent Svendsen, male, age 58, served as chaplain for the military police battalion in Guantanamo from May 2004 to March 2005, working inside Camp Delta for the commanding officer and the troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Howard Taft IV, male, age 67, was Legal Advisor to Secretary of State Colin Powell (2001-2004), and drafted a memo on January 2, 2002 arguing the U.S. should apply the Geneva Conventions to detainees captured in the War on Terror.

did.unittitle: Taft, William Howard, IV - Interview master file
Taft, William Howard, IV - short clip - DeptofDefenseOkaysSuspendingGenevaConvention
Taft, William Howard, IV - short clip - TortureMemosSurprisedStateDept

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Katherine Taylor, female, age 37, is the coordinator of Reprieve's Life after Guantanamo Project, where she facilitates the transfer and resettlement of former Guantanamo detainees to countries across Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ahmed Tourson, male, age 38, a Uyghur from the Xinjiang autonomous region, was detained in Guantanamo from January 21, 2002 until October 31, 2009, when he was released to Palau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ricardo Urbina, male, age 69, was a US District Court Judge in the District of Columbia from 1994 to 2012, serving as Senior Judge from 2011-12. He presided over several Guantanamo habeas corpus cases, including one for seventeen Uyghur prisoners, ordering their release to the U.S. if no other country would take them. His decision was overturned by the Court of Appeals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Darrel Vandeveld, male, age 49, was a prosecutor for the Office of Military Commissions at Guantanamo from June 2007 through September 2008. While acting as the lead prosecutor in the case against Mohammed Jawad, he resigned for ethical reasons and appeared as a witness for the defense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colby Vokey, male, age 47, served as lead counsel to former Guantanamo detainee Omar Khadr, a Canadian who was captured at 15 and was still a juvenile when he was brought to Guantanamo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marilyn Walker, female, age 62, is the mother of John Walker Lindh, a 20 year-old American citizen captured in Afghanistan in November 2001 in connection with his participation in the Taliban, and held for 54 days without access to his family and lawyers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Glendale Walls, male, age 33, was a military intelligence interrogator at Bagram Air Force Base, Afghanistan. He was accused of using abusive interrogation techniques and charged with assaulting and mistreating a detainee, Dilawar of Yakubi, an Afghan taxi driver, who later died at the prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lawrence Wilkerson, male, age 66, is former chief of staff to U.S. Secretary of State, Colin Powell, and former director of the U.S.-Cuba Policy Initiative with the American Strategy Program at the New America Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clint Williamson, male, age 51, was the Ambassador-at-Large for War Crimes Issues from 2006 to 2009, during which he led international resettlement for Guantanamo detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tom Wilner, male, age 66, represented several Kuwaiti detainees before the Supreme Court after being contacted by their families in early 2002. He was Counsel of record to Guantanamo detainees in Rasul v. Bush, decided in June 2004, and counsel of record in Boumediene v. Bush, decided in June 2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lee Wolosky, male, age 48 was appointed Special Envoy for Guantanamo Closure at the U.S. State Department under President Obama from July 5, 2015 until January 20, 2017. During his tenure, the number of men remaining at Guantanamo went from roughly 116 down to 41.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Andy Worthington, male, age 53, a British historian and investigative journalist, is the author of "The Guantanamo Files: The Stories of 759 Detainees in America's Illegal Prison," "The Complete Guantanamo Files," and co-director of the documentary "Outside the Law: Stories of Guantanamo."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen Xenakis, male, age 63, was an Army Brigadier General, and advised senior Department of Defense officials on issues of psychological health. As an expert on torture, he provided legal testimony on behalf of current and former detainees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brahim Yadel, male, age 38, French, was detained in Guantanamo from January 2002 until July 26, 2004, when he was released to France.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview may be accessed only with donor approval, via the electronic records and media computer in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: James Yee, male, age 42, served as the Muslim Chaplain in Guantanamo from November 2002 until September 2003. After being officially recognized for outstanding performance, he was arrested and imprisoned in a Naval brig for 76 days while on leave in Florida. No evidence was released, and eventually all charges were dropped.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mosa Zemmouri, male, age 35, a Belgian citizen of Moroccan heritage, was detained in Guantanamo from February 15, 2002 until April 25, 2005, when he was returned to Belgium.
